comments.commentBody: E-coli and salmonella are natural bacteria found in the wild. They are, by definition, organic.
So you don't get the lovely taste of the mixture of butter/sugar and eggs. and in exchange, your chances of catching Salmonella or E. Coli drop by an immeasurably small amount.

comments.userDisplayName: tired of know it all owners
comments.commentBody: too funny

My refrigerator have alot of water and juice.  It also have alot of junk food because my daughter don't want anything but junk food.  I'm trying to educate her on what foods that are good for her and what foods that are not good for her.  Start off trying to get your kids to eat healthy can be hard but if you teach them how to cook in the kitchen then they will start being interested.

Fresh fruit, eggs, no cheddar cheese unless I'm making mac and cheese, milk, cider, veggies, juice, seltzer, and various other items I need to make a home cooked meal for myself or bake for myself. As for veggies, I love asparagus, Brussel sprouts, spinach, eggplant, etc.

And, if you like your own cooking you're a good cook for yourself. If your family likes it that's even better.

I think part of it is that 'win at any cost' seems to be the way some proceed through life.   Your comment reminds me of the show Survivor and other similar shows, something I really do not like about our culture, this idea of having to win regardless of who may be harmed in the process.

There are actually two different foods that have been identified as 'mincemeat' in different generations. In early America--mid-1800's to 1900's in the mid-west 'mincemeat' actually had meat in it. It was usually used as filling for savory pies. This changed sometime in the mid 1900/s to include raising---then the meat disappeared. It's a very spicy mixture of fruit mainly raisins--with cinnamon and cloves made in the mid-west. Want to know about 'poor man's pie'...also called 'sweet runny pie' that was made by midwestern housewives when all they had in the house in the winter was butter, sugar, flour, and cinnamon.
onions in the fridge?  yuck.

Always: onions, carrots, celery and 1% milk.  The vegetables can always be turned into something delicious with whatever is in the larder and the milk is essential for my cups of tea and oatmeal in the morning.  Eggs? Sometimes.  Cheddar?  Never.

You can't keep artichokes in the fridge for very long,  is one reason. You have to use them pretty much as soon as you get them. Broccoli and zucchini, e.g., will keep a bit longer. I keep grains such as brown rice in the fridge, now, too. Helps them stay fresh longer. Young cooks are probably more enthusiastic about cooking, trying new foods, getting new kitchen gadgets, etc.
I have two jars of homemade mincemeat in my fridge. At Christmas I make English-style mince pies - delicious. Re JJ's comment, mincemeat can be made with meat and fruits, or just fruits alone.
Yeah, I remember when doctors and others thought meat was necessary and being a vegetarian was crazy.  I thought those days were gone.

Read the latest research in medical journals--eating whole soy (in moderation & not processed fake soy junk or fractionated soy protein or supplements) protects against breast cancer in young girls, & recurrences in women who have had breast cancer. Large studies--published in respected journals by respected researchers.

Not all physicians feel comfortable advising their breast cancer patients to eat soy (or are familiar with all the studies)--but it does not cause breast cancer.

"Healthy Librarian" ..Soy Yogurt, Tofu, Tempeh, Soy Milk.....
Soy mimics estrogen;all that soy is a recipe for Breast Cancer. G-d forbid.My cousin, who was raised as a vegetarian, has been advised by her oncologist to EAT MEAT and cease and desist from eating Tofu and all variations thereof, following the removal of her breast, the radiation and Chemotherapy.
As my mother, who eats one square of chocolate a day says" All things in Moderation." and as a sign in her kitchen says" Life's too short- eat dessert fist".
She also taught us that dried fruit is loaded with sugar !

Very interesting. As an experienced kitchen designer and blogger on kitchen design, I'm convinced that many Americans store stuff "just because they can". This stuff is also stored regardless of need or in many cases, a lack of desire to use/eat/enjoy a food or item although it may be perceived to be wanted/used. As a result, more cabinets in the kitchen often mean more stuff, including lots of food, will not be used!

It's a good thing to periodically go through the kitchen to weed out food from both the refrigerator and the pantry to put perspective to what is "really" needed.

(My daughter may or may not have found a jar with an expiration date from 2004 when cooking for Thanksgiving.)

http://www.thekitchendesigner.org
Mincemeat rules! Try it!  Mincemeat cookies especially.  (Packaged mincemeat doesn't really have meat, for the meat-a-phobic.)
People who write cookbooks or sell food or program food shows on TV or edit newspaper sections on Food and Dining. Just to name a few.
Who cares what's in my kitchen besides my husband and me?
Speaking of treats, your poetry's always delish!

Mincemeat can EITHER mean meat that's been minced (think ground beef) OR it can mean a finely chopped mixture of stuff (maybe apples and raisins) possibly including meat (but in modern recipes more often not) that's used as a filling for pies. Mincemeat pies, to be exact.
Perhaps. Edna, were you told that you had wonderful manners growing up?
You bet that, but you have no way of testing it.

SIDEBAR

Your colleague David Brooks reported that about 95% of college professors rated themselves as 'above average.'

[So, it is not surprising that most young cooks rated themselves as "very good." The actual percentage is probably closer to about 16% -- or above two standard deviation above the mean.]
I have mincemeat in my cupboard as well as the big 3
What peppermint ice cream do you buy?  I used to live near Baskin Robbins, which only had it a few months a year, but now I'm in a peppermint ice cream wasteland.

Canned pumpkin is good for dogs with stomach problems. I think I'll get a can in case ours get into something questionable.

We rarely have eggs, but always yogurt and almonds (and other seeds and nuts) and spinach and lots of frozen vegetables. And eggnog in season.

And a big freezer full of lots of other things. We need peppermint ice cream.
This is not an epidemic. This is 80 cases. This is probably a single farm supplying the bad flour.

Aren't "Organic" farms obsessed with not using "chemicals" and so would opt for manure over other fertilizers? So the organic farms are not only unable to protect the plants completely from animals, they are intentionally dumping feces on their plants.

This seems like a risk worth taking on rare occasion, given the great pleasure in eating raw cookie dough (homemade especially), versus a miniscule chance of being sick.  What's the risk - 0.00001%?  There's a much greater risk of cutting your life short by a prevalent but slow killer such as overeating or lack of exercise.

Correct me if I'm wrong, but I suspect the dangers of alcohol still grossly outweigh the dangers of raw cookie dough for those college students.

If anything this is a warning against our negligently thrown together industrial food system, rather than against a culinary practice dating back as long as our species has known how to bake. Show me a person who didn't at minimum lick the bowl when their grandma (or auntie, or whoever) was baking, and I'll show you someone who was never a child. The fact that the flour turns out to be more dangerous than the eggs tells you how fundamentally we've twisted the way we eat.
